entries.text: When I announced the course I offered a 81% discount for 3 days. I'd like to offer this discount to you, the reader of the Perl Weekly as well: Until the 15th December 2011 you'll be able to buy the advanced course for $9 instead of $49 using the 'advanced_intro_9' coupon. The two parts of the Beginner course also have discount codes: 'beginner_15' and 'beginner2_15' respectively for $15 instead of $39 each.
entries.title: Advanced Perl Maven online video course

entries.text: Joel Berger announces a new version of the Perl shell. Cleaned and washed and ready to party.
entries.title: The Triumphant Return of Zoidberg -- A Modular Perl Shell

entries.text: Mark Keating (MDK) writes about the W3C competition and about the only Perl team that participated. And won. Leaving 46 other teams wishing they had better tools.
entries.title: Perl Rocks Latin America

entries.text: Reini Urban gives us a couple of examples where little, innocent looking modules eat up a lot of memory. He also points to tools to check memory footprint. Memory optimization might be an important field we have been neglecting in the Perl/CPAN community. Or maybe it's just me.
entries.title: use B::Stats to check for less bloat

entries.text: In Perl, every scalar variable has both a string value and a numerical value. Usually they are related. brian d foy shows how to create such variables using Scalar::Util.
entries.title: Create your own dualvars

entries.text: It's always fascinating to see a fight between man and machine. This time it is Ricardo Signes (RJBS) who had to deal with Encode, folding and Tibetian e-mail messages.
entries.title: rjbs versus Encode

entries.text: chromatic explains how to change the name of your process as seen by 'ps' or 'top' on Linux.
entries.title: Track App Progress with Writable $0

entries.text: If you have been following the posts of Jeffrey Kegler - and I saw many people clicked on those links - then you might be interested in the second part of this article.
entries.title: How to parse HTML, part 2

entries.text: I love the way Chisel explains how to get people to start thinking about a problem they face. It isn't always possible but I think it can work very well. Much better than saying RTFM or by giving them the solution.
entries.title: The Ten Minute Thinking Rule

entries.text: Joel Berger is doing scientific simulations so he needed complex types that understand things like ft/s  (or m/s for those in the metric system).
entries.title: Announcing MooseX::Types::NumUnit for scientific simulations

entries.text: Graham Knop, who almost never uses Perl on Windows, invested his time creating a way to escape all the characters that need to be escaped on Windows. This sounds a lot simpler than it is. I wish someone packaged this solution and put it on CPAN.
entries.title: Using system or exec safely on Windows

entries.text: Usually I don't link to the small blog entries regarding next years YAPC::NA but this one I liked very much. 'Mob Rater' lets you suggest ideas for YAPC::NA and vote on the other ideas already listed. I think this is a nice idea and the results could be used by any YAPC or Perl workshop. So go ahead, put in your suggestions and vote on the other ones.
entries.title: YAPC::NA has a suggestion box that you can vote on

entries.text: This weeks 'top 10 Perl on Stack Overflow' got some very interesting links. Thanks to Miguel Prz (niceperl) for collecting them week after week.
entries.title: (vi) stackoverflow perl report
